arch:property.oc:show_val: glass beads from child burial octagonal bead relates this burial to Locus 4036

multi-colored, iridescent glass beads; probably late; one string, collected in two KTs child burial (age 2-4yrs); contained no other grave goods
only child burials excavated this season in A4 had grave goods; one infant burial (6 mo. old) and all of the adult burials at the site contained no grave goods this season.
possible Roman or medieval dating per Nevim Hanim.
See also A4TrenchSummary2002.doc for excel spread sheet with burial data. See also Rickland folder on server.
part 1 of 2: SEQUENCE OF 1 clear dark blue round bead (0.5cm), 1 clear sky blue barrel shaped bead (0.5cm), 1 clear dark blue round bead (0.7cm), 1 clear dark blue round bead (0.5cm), 1 round sky blue clear glass bead (0.4cm), 1 dusky orange barrel shaped bead (0.6cm) with dark brown opaque surface decay, 2 dark blue barrel shaped clear glass beads (0.5cm), 1 brilliant turquoise clear glass round bead (0.6cm), 2 dark blue clear glass round beads (0.4cm), 1 clear gray glass round bead (0.5cm), 1 barrel shaped dark blue clear glass bead (0.6cm long), 1 bright orange translucent glass bead with twisted octagonal faceting and smooth edges (1cm), 1 barrel shaped dark blue clear glass bead (0.6cm long), 1 translucent gray round glass bead (0.5cm), 1 sky blue transparent glass bead (0.3cm) with iridescent seagreen surface decay, 1 dark blue clear glass round bead (0.4cm). ALL OF THESE BEADS HAVE IRIDESCENT SURFACE DECAY, BUT ONLY THE ESPECIALLY NOTEWORTHY EXAMPLES ARE NOTED IN THE DESCRIPTION ABOVE. Conservation note: this string of beads is packaged in exactly the same way as part 2 of 2, but is in much better state of preservation; the surface decay is not flaking off severely yet.
part 2 of 2: SEQUENCE OF 10 clear round glass beads (ave. 0.5cm) with gray surface decay, 1 burgundy barrel-shaped stone bead (1cm), 6 glass beads (ave 0.4cm) with white surface decay, 1 glass (?) barrel shaped bead (0.5cm) with white surface decay, 1 orange tube-shaped glass bead with convex sides and iridescent decay, 2 clear glass beads (ave. 0.4cm) with dark surface decay, 2 mustard yellow round stone beads, 1 clear orange glass round bead (0.5cm) with dark brown surface decay, 3 clear lavender and blue glass beads (ave. 0.4cm) with gray surface decay, 1 mustard yellow round stone bead, 2 clear blue round glass beads (0.4cm) with gray surface decay, 1 dark gray round stone bead (0.5cm), 6 clear glass round beads (ave. 0.5cm) with sometimes iridescent light gray surface decay, 1 mustard yellow round stone bead (0.4cm), 1 dark brown round stone bead (0.4cm), 1 clear white round glass bead (0.4cm) with iridescent white surface decay, 1 mustard yellow round stone bead (0.3cm), 3 round glass beads (0.4cm) with gray surface decay, 1 light opaque green glass barrel shaped bead (0.4cm) with green surface decay, 1 round clear blue glass bead (0.8cm) with light gray surface decay, 1 dark blue glass bead (0.4cm) with dark gray surface decay, 2 glass beads (0.5cm) with light gray surface decay, 1 opaque turquoise-colored glass bead (0.6cm), 1 squared-barrel shaped dark glass bead (0.5cm), 4 dark round glass beads (0.5cm) with dark gray surface decay, 1 mustard colored stone? bead (0.4cm), 1 dark-1white1dark glass bead with iridescent surface decay, 1 mustard yellow stone? bead (0.5cm), 2 dark round glass beads with light gray iridescent surface decay, 2 blue glass beads (0.5cm) with light gray iridescent surface decay, 1 dark opaque glass bead (0.4cm), 1 barrel shaped opaque turquoise colored bead (4cm diam x 0.5cm long), 1 dark glass bead (0.4cm) with white and mustard yellow surface decay, 3 clear glass beads (0.4cm) with light gray iridescent surface decay, 1 opaque glass barrel shaped turquoise colored bead (0.3cm). CONSERVATION NOTE: upon rinsing gently with plain tap water most of these beads appeared to be clear/transparent glass when held up in sunlight and most had iridescent surface decay. The beads are strung together on plain dental floss and packed with plain facial cotton into a transparent white plastic (recycle type 4) camera film canister. CONCERN: the rate of decay on all of the beads appears to have accelerated significantly--many are no longer translucent and the surface decay is flaking off in large amounts.

arch:note.arch:string: Finds Bags, or KT bags, are groups of artifacts of the same material composition excavated from a locus. Each finds bag may contain a number of finds but finds are always separated by material. Thus, ceramics, bones and lithics excavated from the same locus were given separate numbers and were collected in separate bags. A special category is the "small find," which could be of any material. Small finds are generally speaking rare or exceptional finds such as figurines, loom weights, andirons or worked bone tools. Small finds are given separate numbers and are bagged separately. Finds bags could consist of only one plastic bag of material and could only be excavated on a single day.

oc:metadata.dc:title: Kenan Tepe: Area A / Trench 4 / Locus 4024 / Finds Bag 2 (Sample)
